py-tidymodels
  • py-tune: Hyperparameter Tuning
  • View page source

py-tune: Hyperparameter Tuning

The py_tune package provides grid search and hyperparameter optimization with cross-validation.

Core Classes

class py_tune.TuneResults(metrics=<factory>, predictions=<factory>, workflow=None, resamples=None, grid=<factory>)[source]

Bases: object

Results from hyperparameter tuning.

Stores metrics, predictions, and parameter configurations from tuning.

metrics: DataFrame
predictions: DataFrame
workflow: Any = None
resamples: Any = None
grid: DataFrame
collect_metrics()[source]

Collect all metrics from tuning.

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with metrics for each configuration

collect_predictions()[source]

Collect all predictions from tuning.

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with predictions for each configuration

show_best(metric, n=5, maximize=True)[source]

Show the best n parameter configurations.

Parameters:

  • metric (str) Metric name to rank by

  • n (int) Number of top configurations to show

  • maximize (bool) Whether to maximize the metric (False to minimize)

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with top n configurations

select_best(metric, maximize=True)[source]

Select the best parameter configuration.

Parameters:

  • metric (str) Metric name to rank by

  • maximize (bool) Whether to maximize the metric (False to minimize)

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Returns:

Dictionary of best parameters

select_by_one_std_err(metric, maximize=True)[source]

Select best configuration using the one-standard-error rule.

Chooses the simplest model within one standard error of the best performance.

Parameters:

  • metric (str) Metric name to rank by

  • maximize (bool) Whether to maximize the metric (False to minimize)

Return type:

Dict[str, Any]

Returns:

Dictionary of selected parameters

__init__(metrics=<factory>, predictions=<factory>, workflow=None, resamples=None, grid=<factory>)

Main Functions

Tuning

py_tune.tune(id=None)[source]

Mark a parameter for tuning.

Parameters:

id (Optional[str]) Optional identifier for the parameter

Return type:

TuneParameter

Returns:

TuneParameter marker object

Examples

>>> spec = linear_reg(penalty=tune(), mixture=tune())
py_tune.tune_grid(workflow, resamples, grid=None, metrics=None, param_info=None, control=None)[source]

Tune workflow hyperparameters via grid search.

Parameters:

  • workflow Workflow object with tune() placeholders

  • resamples Resampling object

  • grid (Union[int, DataFrame, None]) Either integer (number of levels) or DataFrame of parameter combinations

  • metrics Metric set or list of metrics

  • param_info (Optional[Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]]) Parameter information for grid generation (required if grid is int)

  • control (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) Optional control parameters

Return type:

TuneResults

Returns:

TuneResults object with metrics across all configurations

Examples

>>> from py_tune import tune, tune_grid, grid_regular
>>>
>>> # Create workflow with tunable parameters
>>> spec = linear_reg(penalty=tune(), mixture=tune())
>>> wf = workflow().add_formula("y ~ x").add_model(spec)
>>>
>>> # Define parameter space
>>> param_info = {
...     'penalty': {'range': (0.001, 1.0), 'trans': 'log'},
...     'mixture': {'range': (0, 1)}
... }
>>>
>>> # Run grid search
>>> results = tune_grid(wf, folds, param_info=param_info, grid=5)
py_tune.fit_resamples(workflow, resamples, metrics=None, control=None)[source]

Fit a workflow to resamples without tuning.

Evaluates a single workflow configuration across multiple resamples (e.g., cross-validation folds).

Parameters:

  • workflow Workflow object to fit

  • resamples Resampling object (from py_rsample)

  • metrics Metric set or list of metrics (from py_yardstick)

  • control (Optional[Dict[str, Any]]) Optional control parameters

Return type:

TuneResults

Returns:

TuneResults object with metrics and predictions

Examples

>>> from py_workflows import workflow
>>> from py_parsnip import linear_reg
>>> from py_rsample import vfold_cv
>>> from py_yardstick import metric_set, rmse, mae
>>>
>>> wf = workflow().add_formula("y ~ x").add_model(linear_reg())
>>> folds = vfold_cv(data, v=5)
>>> my_metrics = metric_set(rmse, mae)
>>>
>>> results = fit_resamples(wf, folds, metrics=my_metrics)

Grid Generation

py_tune.grid_regular(param_info, levels=3)[source]

Create a regular grid of parameter values.

Parameters:

  • param_info (Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]) Dictionary mapping parameter names to their specifications Each spec should have range or values key Optionally include type: int to convert to integers

  • levels (int) Number of levels for each parameter (default: 3)

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with one row per parameter combination

Examples

>>> param_info = {
...     'penalty': {'range': (0.001, 1.0), 'trans': 'log'},
...     'mixture': {'range': (0, 1)},
...     'trees': {'range': (50, 200), 'type': 'int'}
... }
>>> grid = grid_regular(param_info, levels=3)
py_tune.grid_random(param_info, size=10, seed=None)[source]

Create a random grid of parameter values.

Parameters:

  • param_info (Dict[str, Dict[str, Any]]) Dictionary mapping parameter names to their specifications

  • size (int) Number of random combinations to generate

  • seed (Optional[int]) Random seed for reproducibility

Return type:

DataFrame

Returns:

DataFrame with one row per parameter combination

Examples

>>> param_info = {
...     'penalty': {'range': (0.001, 1.0), 'trans': 'log'},
...     'trees': {'range': (10, 1000), 'type': 'int'}
... }
>>> grid = grid_random(param_info, size=20, seed=42)

Finalization

py_tune.finalize_workflow(workflow, best_params)[source]

Finalize a workflow with the best parameters.

Parameters:

  • workflow Original workflow with tune() placeholders

  • best_params (Dict[str, Any]) Dictionary of best parameter values

Returns:

Finalized workflow ready for fitting

Examples

>>> results = tune_grid(wf, folds, grid=grid)
>>> best = results.select_best('rmse', maximize=False)
>>> final_wf = finalize_workflow(wf, best)
>>> final_fit = final_wf.fit(train_data)

Examples

Basic Tuning

from py_tune import tune, tune_grid, grid_regular, finalize_workflow
from py_workflows import workflow
from py_parsnip import linear_reg
from py_rsample import vfold_cv
from py_yardstick import metric_set, rmse, r_squared

# Mark parameters for tuning
spec = linear_reg(penalty=tune(), mixture=tune())

# Create workflow
wf = workflow().add_formula("y ~ .").add_model(spec)

# Create parameter grid
grid = grid_regular({
    "penalty": {"range": (0.001, 1.0), "trans": "log"},
    "mixture": {"range": (0, 1)}
}, levels=5)

# Create resamples
folds = vfold_cv(train_data, v=5)

# Tune grid search
results = tune_grid(
    wf,
    resamples=folds,
    grid=grid,
    metrics=metric_set(rmse, r_squared)
)

Analyze Results

# Show best models
best = results.show_best("rmse", n=5, maximize=False)
print(best)

# Select best by metric
best_params = results.select_best("rmse", maximize=False)

# Select by one-std-error rule
simple_params = results.select_by_one_std_err(
    "rmse",
    maximize=False,
    metric="penalty"
)

Finalize Workflow

# Apply best parameters
final_wf = finalize_workflow(wf, best_params)

# Fit on full training data
final_fit = final_wf.fit(train_data)

# Evaluate on test data
final_fit = final_fit.evaluate(test_data)
outputs, coefs, stats = final_fit.extract_outputs()

Random Grid

from py_tune import grid_random

# Random parameter sampling
grid = grid_random({
    "penalty": {"range": (0.001, 1.0), "trans": "log"},
    "mixture": {"range": (0, 1)},
    "tree_depth": {"range": (3, 10)}
}, size=20, seed=123)

# Tune with random grid
results = tune_grid(wf, resamples=folds, grid=grid, metrics=metrics)

Fit Resamples Without Tuning

from py_tune import fit_resamples

# Evaluate fixed model across resamples
spec = linear_reg()  # No tune() markers
wf = workflow().add_formula("y ~ .").add_model(spec)

results = fit_resamples(
    wf,
    resamples=folds,
    metrics=metric_set(rmse, mae, r_squared)
)

# Aggregate metrics
mean_metrics = results.collect_metrics()
